newsitem.title: UK: Precious metals slump as demand expected to rise.
newsitem.headline: Precious metals slump as demand expected to rise.

text.p: Just as seasonal demand for precious metals is picking up, prices have tumbled.

Gold is weak. Silver is at an 18-month low. Platinum and palladium are cheaper than at any time in three years. And the retreat may continue amid fiercely bearish sentiment even as demand strengthens, analysts said.
"If there is a view in the market, it is usually strong enough to override the seasonal factor," bullion analyst Andy Smith of Union Bank of Switzerland said on Wednesday.
"It seems since the end of August the (investment) funds have had a view, and they're pessimistic," he added.
Typically, the middle of September is a signal for an increase in gold demand from Asia as well as from U.S. and European jewellery fabricators.

But any seasonal boost has been overshadowed so far by a big speculative play led by U.S. funds last week. It sent silver plunging below its key $5 an ounce level, and its weakness has spilled over into the other precious metals.
Gold, already stuck in a protracted downtrend, reacted to silver's sell-off by easing to fresh two-month lows just above the technically significant $380 an ounce level.
Bullion fixed at $383.25 an ounce on Wednesday, compared to around $415 at the start of the year.
Technical analysts who study charts of historical prices to calculate future trends, said gold's staying power above $380 held the key to the rest of the precious metals.
"We've got a divergence between gold and silver at the moment, where silver seems to be breaking down and gold isn't," said Cliff Green of Trend Analysis.
"It's all eyes on gold -- if it remains above $380, then maybe there's upside potential for silver." If not, however, the complex is liable to crumble further.
Silver had dropped to 18-month lows last week and was still vulnerable to losses to as low as $4.50 an ounce, Green said.
On Wednesday it was off lows but still vulnerable at around $4.94 an ounce. Silver, an industrial metal, is more volatile than gold and therefore an obvious target for speculators.
"It's very easy to move the silver market around and I guess people got tired of waiting for see prices move up to $6," said Kevin Crisp, an analyst at JP Morgan.
Platinum and palladium have also come under pressure from silver after being undermined over the summer by steady supplies from producer Russia and slack industrial demand.
Platinum has hovered around 2-1/2 year lows in recent days and its stablemate palladium dipped to three-year lows.
Analysts said demand for gold bullion will rise as jewellers establish inventories for Christmas and Chinese New Year.
"Demand is looking reasonably good at this point," said Crisp of J.P. Morgan. "The sentiment is uniformly bearish for the metals, but that could mean there are some surprises in store."

But so far, the demand trickling in has done little more than put support under the market rather than lead prices up. "The physical demand is taking up the surplus and slowing the decline. It's not enough to tip the balance," a dealer said.
That's because professional investors have turned up their noses at the precious metals.
Gold's traditionally role as a "safe haven" in times of political and economic crisis has been called into question as investors turn to more profitable stocks and bonds.
A proposal by the International Monetary Fund to sell some gold reserves has also cast a pall on gold, though analysts say the market would easily absorb the amount in question.
"Funds are fickle, they don't care if it's gold or green cheese. They bought it in January, they're selling it now. The flucutations and flows are background noise," UBS's Smith said.
